image.altText: A composite image showing a man in a suit in an office and the exterior of a law firm's office.

items.synopsis: A suspected Ponzi scheme that has ensnared Melbourne racing identities and a senior AFL figure was offering returns of up to 8 per cent before the sudden death of its alleged mastermind last month.

title.children: Melbourne lawyer's suspected $100 million Ponzi scheme could dwarf Melissa Caddick fraud

image.altText: soldiers advancing in smoke

items.synopsis: Israel's defence force chief of staff says forces are operating in Gaza City after encircling it from several directions, while the US calls for a series of pauses in fighting to allow aid in and foreign nationals out.

title.children: Israel says troops are operating in Gaza City as US presses for pauses in fighting

image.altText: Gaza strip

items.synopsis: Seven United Nations special rapporteurs issue a warning, but Israel says it is aiming its attacks at Hamas not civilians. Follow live.

title.children: UN experts warn Palestinians are at 'grave risk of genocide' as Israel says it is making advances

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by ABC producer Chérine Yazbeck in Beirut On October 7, when Hamas-led militants launched their attack on Israel, Ghassan Abu Sittah was in London. The surgeon has a very successful practice in the UK. But when he saw the news, he immediately booked his flights and began his journey towards Gaza. The British-Palestinian doctor knew the attack would likely lead to a ground incursion of the coastal enclave. Fearing a crisis would befall Gaza's hospitals, he wanted to be there to treat patients with critical conditions. "I studied in London but did my internship during the conflict in Lebanon in 1996," he told the ABC. "I have a long experience of working in conflict zones — Iraq, Syria, Lebanon and Gaza." He says the health system in the region is falling apart, with patients sleeping in corridors. He also says conditions in the hospitals in Gaza are so bad he's resorted to using vinegar as disinfectant.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The London-based surgeon who flew to Gaza when war broke out to treat patients

children.content: Reporting by ABC producer Chérine Yazbeck in Beirut
On October 7, when Hamas-led militants launched their attack on Israel, Ghassan Abu Sittah was in London.
The surgeon has a very successful practice in the UK. But when he saw the news, he immediately booked his flights and began his journey towards Gaza.
Ghassan Abu Sittah left London for Gaza when war broke out.
(Supplied: Ghassan Abu Sitta)
The British-Palestinian doctor knew the attack would likely lead to a ground incursion of the coastal enclave.
Fearing a crisis would befall Gaza's hospitals, he wanted to be there to treat patients with critical conditions.
"I studied in London but did my internship during the conflict in Lebanon in 1996," he told the ABC.
"I have a long experience of working in conflict zones — Iraq, Syria, Lebanon and Gaza."
He says the health system in the region is falling apart, with patients sleeping in corridors.
He also says conditions in the hospitals in Gaza are so bad he's resorted to using vinegar as disinfectant.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two men have been fined after a display honouring Israeli hostages taken by Hamas was allegedly damaged in Sydney's east. The pair allegedly tore down towels, pairs of thongs and photos representing the 240 hostages along the promenade at Bondi Beach yesterday. Police say the two men, aged 25 and 40, have each been fined $500 for offensive behaviour.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Men fined after display of Israeli hostages allegedly damaged at Bondi Beach

children.content: Two men have been fined after a display honouring Israeli hostages taken by Hamas was allegedly damaged in Sydney's east.
The pair allegedly tore down towels, pairs of thongs and photos representing the 240 hostages along the promenade at Bondi Beach yesterday.
Police say the two men, aged 25 and 40, have each been fined $500 for offensive behaviour.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As the death toll in Gaza approaches 10,000, there have been growing calls within the international community for a ceasefire. The US remains formally opposed to that. But White House officials, from the president down, have been talking more and more about their desire to see "pauses" in the war. It's likely to be raised as a priority by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken when he meets Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He's on his way to Israel now. White House national security spokesman John Kirby briefed reporters here in Washington earlier: "We're really not just talking about, like, one pause. "What we're trying to do is explore the idea of as many pauses as might be necessary to continue to get aid out, and to continue to work to get people out safely, including hostages. "The president already worked on one such pause when we were able to get those two Americans out. And that's what we're kind of looking at." On Wednesday (local time), Joe Biden voiced support for a humanitarian pause after a protester interrupted a speech he was giving in Minnesota. “As a rabbi, I need you to call for a ceasefire right now," yelled the protester, who later identified herself to reporters as Rabbi Jessica Rosenberg from the anti-Zionist Jewish Voice for Peace group. "I think we need a pause," Biden replied, according to a pool reporter at the event. "A pause means give time to get the prisoners out." Yesterday, Foreign Minister Penny Wong reiterated Australia's call for humanitarian pauses .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The White House's push for 'pause'

children.content: As the death toll in Gaza approaches 10,000, there have been growing calls within the international community for a ceasefire.
The US remains formally opposed to that. But White House officials, from the president down, have been talking more and more about their desire to see "pauses" in the war.
It's likely to be raised as a priority by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken when he meets Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He's on his way to Israel now.
White House national security spokesman John Kirby briefed reporters here in Washington earlier:
"We're really not just talking about, like, one pause.
"What we're trying to do is explore the idea of as many pauses as might be necessary to continue to get aid out, and to continue to work to get people out safely, including hostages.
"The president already worked on one such pause when we were able to get those
two Americans out
. And that's what we're kind of looking at."

props.alt: John Kirby speaks and gestures with his hand, standing in the White House press room.

children.content: John Kirby at a White House press conference earlier today.
(AP: Evan Vucci)
On Wednesday (local time), Joe Biden voiced support for a humanitarian pause after a protester interrupted a speech he was giving in Minnesota.

“As a rabbi, I need you to call for a ceasefire right now," yelled the protester, who later identified herself to reporters as Rabbi Jessica Rosenberg from the anti-Zionist Jewish Voice for Peace group.
"I think we need a pause," Biden replied, according to a pool reporter at the event. "A pause means give time to get the prisoners out."
Yesterday, Foreign Minister
Penny Wong reiterated Australia's call for humanitarian pauses

image.altText: Two Qantas planes parked on a tarmac at an airport with a Qantas-branded shed in the background.

items.synopsis: Qantas is holding its AGM this morning, just a few days after the airline defended itself against so-called "ghost flight" allegations. Meanwhile, Australian Clinical Labs is facing a court case over a data hack last year. Read about it on our live blog.

title.children: Qantas faces shareholder revolt at its AGM after turbulent year, ASX jumps after Wall Street bounce

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas chair Richard Goyder has just run through how voting will work for shareholders, and how questions will be asked. We're starting with a question from Australian Shareholders Association, asked by CEO Rachel Waterhouse. She asks Mr Goyder the total value of flight credits on the balance sheet, and if the rate of customer complaints have reduced. She's also asked about a compensation figure for the 1,700 workers illegally sacked by Qantas, as per the High Court's decision a few months ago. Mr Goyder replies that the flight credit is now $520 million, and the airline has paid back $1.25 billion worth of credits. Ms Hudson follows up saying Qantas is focused on credits being redeemed or refunded, and they have "100 dedicated agents" in its call centres to ensure customers can access those funds. "We are going to be unrelenting in the way in which we contact customers, and we've started SMSing customers ... and we've noticed that's driven a lot of uptick [in refunds]," she says. She also notes that credits will never expire, "and we're not going to stop until that balance is zero". On the ground handling issue, Mr Goyder says Ms Hudson will be leading that process in terms of compensation. He says it would be inappropriate right now to discuss compensation regarding the High Court decision. "I guess we assume it's a significant amount?" Ms Waterhouse queries. Mr Goyder replies that they are still working through the compensation process.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The first question from shareholders is on flight credits and ground crew compensation

children.content: Qantas chair Richard Goyder has just run through how voting will work for shareholders, and how questions will be asked.
We're starting with a question from Australian Shareholders Association, asked by CEO Rachel Waterhouse.
She asks Mr Goyder the total value of flight credits on the balance sheet, and if the rate of customer complaints have reduced.
She's also asked about a compensation figure for the 1,700 workers illegally sacked by Qantas, as per the High Court's decision a few months ago.
Mr Goyder replies that the flight credit is now $520 million, and the airline has paid back $1.25 billion worth of credits.
Ms Hudson follows up saying Qantas is focused on credits being redeemed or refunded, and they have "100 dedicated agents" in its call centres to ensure customers can access those funds.
"We are going to be unrelenting in the way in which we contact customers, and we've started SMSing customers ... and we've noticed that's driven a lot of uptick [in refunds]," she says.
She also notes that credits will never expire, "and we're not going to stop until that balance is zero".
On the ground handling issue, Mr Goyder says Ms Hudson will be leading that process in terms of compensation.
He says it would be inappropriate right now to discuss compensation regarding the High Court decision.
"I guess we assume it's a significant amount?" Ms Waterhouse queries.
Mr Goyder replies that they are still working through the compensation process.

props.alt: A photo of green theatre chairs in a room with  people on stage and on a projector.

children.content: Chairman Richard Goyder and CEO Vanessa Hudson are now taking questions from shareholders and advisory groups.
(ABC News: Nassim Khadem)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: My colleague, business reporter Nassim Khadem, is in the room at the Qantas AGM, and says it's very quiet while Mr Goyder and Ms Hudson were speaking. She says investors are listening intently, but noted that one person made a funny noise when Mr Goyder was discussing Alan Joyce's performance as CEO. There are 80 shareholders physically in the room in Melbourne. Here's some photos from inside the room:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The mood inside the Qantas AGM

children.content: My colleague,
business reporter Nassim Khadem,
is in the room at the Qantas AGM, and says it's very quiet while Mr Goyder and Ms Hudson were speaking.
She says investors are listening intently, but noted that one person made a funny noise when Mr Goyder was discussing Alan Joyce's performance as CEO.
There are 80 shareholders physically in the room in Melbourne.
Here's some photos from inside the room:

props.alt: People sit in a theatre with people sitting on a stage with a Qantas plane tail on a projector.

children.content: Qantas' executive team faces a room full of shareholders.
(ABC News: Nassim Khadem)

props.alt: A woman speaks behind a lecturn.

children.content: CEO Vanessa Hudson delivering her speech.
(ABC News: Nassim Khadem)

props.alt: People sitting in green theatre seats in a room with red lights projected onto the walls.

children.content: Some shareholders attending the AGM appeared unimpressed listening to the CEO's speech.
(ABC News: Nassim Khadem)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wrapping up her speech, Ms Hudson finishes saying that Qantas is determined to tackle its "big challenges" and has an "exciting future". "Later this month, Qantas will turn 103.  There are few companies in Australia, and even fewer airlines globally, that have reached that milestone," she says. "While we arrive at this moment with some big challenges, we also have enormous opportunities and an  exciting future. "A future that will see our brand recover, our fleet renew, our network expand, our emissions reduce and  our people offered more opportunities. "Collectively, we have the experience, the focus, energy, and the financial strength to achieve this. And we intend to restore your trust in the process."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas faces 'big challenges' and 'enormous opportunities', Hudson says

children.content: Wrapping up her speech, Ms Hudson finishes saying that Qantas is determined to tackle its "big challenges" and has an "exciting future".
"Later this month, Qantas will turn 103.  There are few companies in Australia, and even fewer airlines globally, that have reached that milestone," she says.
"While we arrive at this moment with some big challenges, we also have enormous opportunities and an  exciting future.
"A future that will see our brand recover, our fleet renew, our network expand, our emissions reduce and  our people offered more opportunities.
"Collectively, we have the experience, the focus, energy, and the financial strength to achieve this. And we intend to restore your trust in the process."

image.altText: Mohammed Siraj runs away with arms outstretched after a Sri Lankan wicket at the Cricket World Cup.
